For example:```consolepython3 -m venv visualizer-env. visualizer-env/bin/activate```Inside the virtual environment, install the application from `pip`:```consolepip install robot-log-visualizer```### ğŸ‘· Install the latest version (not recommended)If you want to use the latest feature of the `robot-log-visualizer` you can install it with thefollowing command```consolepython -m pip install git+https://github.com/ami-iit/robot-log-visualizer.git```## ğŸƒ UsageOnce you have installed the `robot-log-visualizer` you can run it from the terminal[robot-log-visualizer.webm](https://github.com/ami-iit/robot-log-visualizer/assets/16744101/3fd5c516-da17-4efa-b83b-392b5ce1383b)You can navigate the dataset thanks to the slider or by pressing `Ctrl-f` and `Ctrl-b` to moveforward and backward.### ğŸ’¡ Environment variables`robot-log-visualizer` looks for the model in the folders pointed by one of the following environment variables:`GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`, `ROS_PACKAGE_PATH`, `AMENT_PREFIX_PATH` Please remember to add your model folder to one of theseenvironment variables.For instance, if you have a model in the folder `~/my-models` you can add it to the `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` with thefollowing command```consoleexport GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=${GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH}:~/my-models ```Where `~/my-models` is the path to your models folder that is structured as follows```consoletree ~/my-models~/my-modelsâ”œâ”€â”€ model1â”‚Â Â  â”œâ”€â”€ model.configâ”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ model.urdfâ””â”€â”€ model2 â”œâ”€â”€ model.config â””â”€â”€ model.urdf```And the name of the robot stored in the `mat` file is `model1` or `model2`.## ğŸ› Bug reports and supportAll types of [issues](https://github.com/ami-iit/robot-log-visualizer/issues/new) are welcome.## ğŸ“ LicenseMaterials in this repository are distributed under the following license:> All software is licensed under the BSD 3-Clause License.
